newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, AMD set power-saving guidelines.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, AMD set power-saving guidelines.

text.p: Microsoft Corp and Advanced Micro Devices Inc on Wednesday unveiled guidelines governing power management that enables personal computers to stay connected to a network when not otherwise in use.

The guidelines, part of an industry effort called the OnNow initiative, define how network-connected computing devices behave and enables "sleeping" PCs to respond to requests from other computers and printers, the companies said.
The electrical supply of an OnNow-enabled PC is always on, but appears off, allowing the PC to respond immediately to user or other requests while still saving power.

The specification also allows PCs to be remotely managed by technicians during off-hours like evenings and weekends. This is accomplished by allowing PCs to enter low-power sleep modes without losing network connections and without changing the network infrastructure.
Network devices based on this specification will have the ability to sort through network traffic and wake up the computer for defined network requests.
Microsoft and AMD proposed the network class specification in August 1996.

Since then, networking companies including 3Com Corp, Crystal Semiconductor, Digital Equipment Corp's Semiconductor unit, Intel Corp and Olicom A/S, and computer system makers Hewlett-Packard Co and International Business Machines Corp, have lent their support to the industry effort.
Products incorporating the new specification are expected in the second half of 1997.
